perturbation.original_text:
2.1. 
Term. The initial term of this Agreement shall commence on the Effective Date, and shall continue thereafter for a period of
twelve (12) months (the “Initial Term”). The Initial Term shall automatically renew for one-month periods thereafter unless either party provides 30-
days advance notice of termination, unless earlier terminated pursuant to Section 2.2 hereof. For purposes hereof, the Initial Term, together with any
extension or renewal terms, shall hereinafter be collectively referred to as the “Term”.
perturbation.changed_text:
2.1. 
Term. The initial term of this Agreement shall commence on the Effective Date, and shall continue thereafter for a period of
twelve (12) months (the “Initial Term”). The Initial Term will renew at the discretion of DSS, taking into account Developer performance. For purposes hereof, the Initial Term, together with any
extension or renewal terms, shall hereinafter be collectively referred to as the “Term”.
perturbation.explanation: The original text indicates automatic renewal with a 30-day notice clause. The modified text introduces uncertainty by stating that renewal is at DSS's discretion, dependent on Developer performance. This contradicts the automatic renewal clause, making the term's length uncertain.

perturbation.original_text:
3.1. 
Subject to Developer’s expressly granted rights under this Agreement, Developer acknowledges and agrees that DSS shall
own all right, title, and interest in and to the Technology, the Improvements, its Intellectual Property, and all future derivative works derived
therefrom or developed hereunder. Developer agrees that it will not at any time (i) do or cause to be done any act or thing contesting or in any way
impairing any part of such right, title and interest or (ii) represent, expressly or by implication that it has any right, title or interest in or to any of the
foregoing other than as expressly set forth herein.
perturbation.changed_text:
3.1. 
Subject to Developer’s expressly granted rights under this Agreement, Developer acknowledges and agrees that DSS shall
own all right, title, and interest in and to the Technology, the Improvements, its Intellectual Property, and all future derivative works derived
therefrom or developed hereunder. Developer may retain limited rights to the Improvements, subject to separate written agreement with DSS. Developer agrees that it will not at any time (i) do or cause to be done any act or thing contesting or in any way
impairing any part of such right, title and interest or (ii) represent, expressly or by implication that it has any right, title or interest in or to any of the
foregoing other than as expressly set forth herein.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause states that DSS owns all rights to Improvements. The modified clause introduces the possibility that Developer may retain some rights subject to a separate agreement. This creates a direct contradiction regarding ownership of Improvements, causing uncertainty.

perturbation.original_text:
6.1. 
Developer Liability for Damages. Developer shall be fully liable, without limitation, for money damages resulting from its
improper or unauthorized use, modification, alteration, licensing or transfer of the Technology or Improvements, or resulting from its failure to
provide functional and merchantable Improvements hereunder, which failure shall be deemed a material breach of this Agreement by Developer.
perturbation.changed_text:
6.1. 
Developer Liability for Damages. Developer shall be liable for money damages resulting from its
improper or unauthorized use, modification, alteration, licensing or transfer of the Technology or Improvements, or resulting from its failure to
provide functional and merchantable Improvements hereunder, which failure shall be deemed a material breach of this Agreement by Developer. Developer liability will be capped at the amount of fees paid by DSS to Developer under this agreement.
perturbation.explanation: The original clause stated that Developer's liability for damages is without limitation. The modified clause then introduces a cap on the liability, limiting it to the amount of fees paid. This contradicts the original statement of unlimited liability, creating uncertainty about the extent of Developer's financial responsibility for damages.
